definition[0]: to express formal support or approval for someone or something
example[0]: The prime minister is unlikely to endorse this view.
note[0]: endorse a proposal/an idea/a candidate etc
definition[1]: if a famous person endorses a product or service, they say in an advertisement that they use and like it
definition[2]: to sign your name on the back of a cheque to show that it is correct
definition[3]: if your driving licence is endorsed for a driving offence, an official record is made on it to show that you are guilty of the offence
explanation[0]: Endorse is usually passive in this meaning
definition[4]: to sign a formal document for something that you own so that ownership changes to someone else
definition[5]: to sign your name on the back of a cheque, a BILL OF EXCHANGE etc so that it can be paid to someone other than the person whose name is written on it
example[1]: The bank could not confirm the endorsed signature so stolen cheques could be cashed long before anyone realised it.
definition[6]: if a well-known person endorses a product, they say in an advertisement how good they think it is. People will buy the product because they like or trust the person
definition[7]: to add a written condition to an insurance agreement
